body: @icing this assert seems to have code handling the case in run-time just following it, so I'm not sure about the importance of this trigger. What do you think?

@bagder when writing this, I *assumed* that subsequent calls would satisfy the assertion. But, given the complexity of the transfer handling, I was not 100% sure.

So, my question would be: is the situation triggered by OSSFuzz also part of "normal" behaviour that we just do not see regularly? How does it trigger?

Architecture is i386. Test case it fails on is like this:

TLVHeader(type='Server response 9' (25), length=13, data=b"<data>")
TLVHeader(type='CURLOPT_HTTP_VERSION' (40), length=4, data=b'<data>')
TLVHeader(type='Server response 2' (18), length=0, data=b'')
TLVHeader(type='CURLOPT_URL' (1), length=34, data=b'<data>')
TLVHeader(type='CURLOPT_USERAGENT' (45), length=34, data=b'<data>')
TLVHeader(type='Server response 1' (17), length=39, data=b'<data>')
TLVHeader(type='Server banner (sent on connection)' (2), length=225, data=b'<data>')
TLVHeader(type='CURLOPT_USERPWD' (44), length=65534, data=b'<data>')

Weirdest thing is probably a 65KB user+password setting...
Interesting, will try to make a test case with this.
I'll try and repro locally too.

issue.title: VLH, very large header test and fixes

repository.name: curl
repository.description: A command line tool and library for transferring data with URL syntax, supporting DICT, FILE, FTP, FTPS, GOPHER, GOPHERS, HTTP, HTTPS, IMAP, IMAPS, LDAP, LDAPS, MQTT, POP3, POP3S, RTMP, RTMPS, RTSP, SCP, SFTP, SMB, SMBS, SMTP, SMTPS, TELNET, TFTP, WS and WSS. libcurl offers a myriad of powerful features

issue.body:
- refs #11500
- adding tests using very large passwords in auth
- fixes general http sending to treat h3 like h2, and not like http1.1
- eliminate H2_HEADER max definitions and use the commmon DYN_HTTP_REQUEST everywhere, different limits do not help
- fix http2 handling of requests denied by nghttp2 on send to immediately report the refused stream

body:
I have gdb working now so I can offer more details about the stack trace if necessary.

```
#5  0x0837d095 in cf_h2_send (cf=0xf2e00914, data=0xf2002a84, buf=0xf308c804, len=65536, err=0xffffb5f0)
    at /src/curl/lib/http2.c:2080
2080          DEBUGASSERT(len >= stream->upload_blocked_len);
(gdb) p len
$1 = 65536
(gdb) p stream->upload_blocked_len
$2 = 81853
```
Is this on the current `master`? Because the `65536` looks suspiciously like a bug I fixed in c76df46a195dff259f2a2716f9f8fb5b7eb89602.
No, it wouldn't be. If it's fixed it's likely to roll through to OSSFuzz in the next day or so.
@icing I've verified this still fails on latest master.

@cmeister2 thanks for testing. Hmm, looking at `Curl_buffer_send()` which should be the one invoking this, I have no trust in this function. @bagder, I think we need to do some reviewing of this thing. I wonder what it does if writing is only partial *twice*. This `http->backup` thing looks suspect.
@icing if it helps I can write down step by step repro instructions

issue.title: Disable asssertion blocking OSSFuzz testing

repository.name: curl
repository.description: A command line tool and library for transferring data with URL syntax, supporting DICT, FILE, FTP, FTPS, GOPHER, GOPHERS, HTTP, HTTPS, IMAP, IMAPS, LDAP, LDAPS, MQTT, POP3, POP3S, RTMP, RTMPS, RTSP, SCP, SFTP, SMB, SMBS, SMTP, SMTPS, TELNET, TFTP, WS and WSS. libcurl offers a myriad of powerful features

issue.body:
- refs #11500
- not clear how this triggers and it blocks OSSFuzz testing other things. Since we handle the case with an error return, disabling the assertion for now seems the best way forward.

body: Just made #11519 where this assertion is disabled, as discussed with @bagder as a way forward until we analyse what really is the root cause here.
